slides.title: The Review That Changed Everything

content.headline: One Review Changed Everything
content.subhead: How a single customer's words became an algorithm
content.visual: Five-star review transforming into code/AI signals

slides.narration: Last year, a bakery in Ohio got a review. Nothing special—just a customer saying the croissants were amazing. Within weeks, AI assistants started recommending them. Not because of ads. Not because of SEO. Because AI learned to trust them. That one review was the tipping point. Let me explain why.

slides.title: How AI Evaluates Trust

content.headline: AI Doesn't Search. AI Evaluates.

signals.weight: How many people are talking about you
Are people still talking about you
Where are these reviews coming from
Do all signals tell the same story

content.key_point: AI builds a 'trust score' from multiple signals

slides.narration: AI doesn't just search for keywords. AI evaluates trust. It looks at review volume—how many people are talking about you. Review quality—what they're actually saying. Review recency—are people still talking about you, or did everyone stop two years ago? Source authority—are these reviews on trusted platforms? And consistency—do all the signals tell the same story? AI builds a trust score from all of this.

slides.title: The Reputation Flywheel

content.headline: Reputation Compounds
content.insight: The businesses with the best reputations get MORE opportunities to build reputation

slides.narration: Here's what makes reputation so powerful: it compounds. Good service creates happy customers. Happy customers leave positive reviews. Positive reviews make AI recommend you. AI recommendations bring new customers. Those new customers, if served well, leave more reviews. The flywheel accelerates. The businesses with the best reputations get more opportunities to build even better reputations. The rich get richer.

slides.title: The Review Velocity Problem

content.headline: It's Not Just Stars. It's Speed.
content.question: Which one does AI trust more?
content.answer: Business B. Velocity signals a living, thriving business.
content.visual: Graph showing review velocity over time

slides.narration: Here's something most people don't realize: it's not just about stars. It's about velocity. Business A has four point eight stars but only gets one review a month—stagnant. Business B has four point five stars but gets eight reviews a month—growing. Which one does AI trust more? Business B. Every time. Velocity signals a living, thriving business. Stagnation signals maybe they've declined. Maybe they've closed. Maybe those old reviews aren't relevant anymore.

slides.title: The Multi-Platform Effect

content.headline: One Platform Isn't Enough

scenario.google_only: 5 stars on Google, nothing elsewhere = AI skeptical
scenario.multi_platform: 4.5 stars across Google, Yelp, Directory, Facebook = AI confident

content.why: Multiple platforms = multiple independent signals = higher trust
content.visual: Single vs. multiple platform presence comparison

slides.narration: One platform isn't enough anymore. Five stars on Google but nothing elsewhere? AI is skeptical. Could be fake. Could be gamed. Could be one platform with a weird algorithm. But four point five stars across Google, Yelp, the directory, and Facebook? Now AI is confident. Multiple platforms mean multiple independent signals. Different people, different contexts, all saying the same thing. That's trust you can't fake.

slides.title: From Invisible to Recommended

case_study.business: Auto repair shop, 20 years in business
action: Responded to every review (positive and negative)
Asked happy customers for specific feedback
case_study.before: 2 reviews/month, not appearing in AI results

slides.narration: Auto repair shop, twenty years in business. Excellent service—everyone who went there loved them. Problem: almost no reviews. Two a month, maybe. Never appeared in AI results. They implemented a simple review request system. Started responding to every review. Got listed on multiple platforms. Asked happy customers to mention specific things they appreciated. Ninety days later: fifteen reviews a month. AI recommends them regularly. Same great service. Now everyone knows about it.
